loans.use: buy construction materials

loans.name: Munhtuya

texts.en:
Munhtuya is 45 years old and lives with her son in a rented apartment in the Suhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son is 14 years old and attends a secondary school.

Munhtuya runs a construction material trading business from a rented stall at a trading center. She started her business in 2007 and has gained much experience. Recently, she began renting one more stall in order to increase her sales channel.  She is a polite woman who says, "I want to have my own house in the future."  

Munhtuya is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials from China to sell this coming summer.

loans.use: buy construction materials

loans.name: 45.thiệu Dương-Thiệu Hoá Group

texts.en:
Chuc is 53 years old.  She is married and has 3 children and supports 1 additional dependent.  She is the group leader of the 9.1.45.Thieu Duong solidarity group, which consists of 3 members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a  rural area in Thanh Hoa province.  

Chuc works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle.  She has been involved in this business for 8 years.   She is requesting a loan to invest in her business. This is her first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women.

The main harship that Chuc faces in her business is the lack of capital.  With her profits, she hopes to make her business more successful and to remodel her house.

loans.use: buy baby livestock

loans.name: Dalelhan

texts.en:
Dalelhan is 56 years old and lives with his wife and son in a house in Hovd province in Mongolia. His son is a driver who owns a taxi service and his wife, age 54, is retired.  

Dalelhan is a technician for a private company and also conducts a vegetable farming and trading business in his town. He started his business in 2006.  Now he owns 1 hectare of land where he plants daily consumption vegetables. Dalelhan is a kind man who is planning to expand his business.  He is requesting a loan for 2,000,000 MNT to purchase seeds for his business.

loans.use: purchase seeds

loans.name: Virgilia

texts.en:
Virgilia is married and 48 years old. She has a food stall where she sells fruits and vegetables. Virgilia has had this business for four years.

Virgilia is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase bananas, apples, carrots, cabbage and squash to sell. Each month, Virgilia earns about PHP 4,000 by selling fruits and vegetables.

In the future, Virgilia hopes that her business will improve to support the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase bananas, apples, carrots, cabbage and squash to sell

loans.name: Sharavnyambuu

texts.en:
Sharavnyambuu is 45 years old and lives with his wife and son in a house in Govi-Altai province in Mongolia. His son is a student and his wife helps with the family business. 

Sharavnyambuu runs an auto parts trading business at a local market. He started his business with a working capital of 200,000 MNT in 2002.  In the winter, he also operates a meat trading business in order to supplement his earnings.  Sharavnyambuu is planning to plant trees this coming summer.  He now owns 1 hectare of land where he will plant 2500 trees.  He is a hardworking man who is planning to buy a car with his earnings. 

Sharavnyambuu is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase seeds for his business.

loans.use: purchase seeds

loans.name: Ronaldo

texts.en: Ronaldo, 37 years of age, is married and blessed with two children. He has operated a retail store in their village for almost three years. His monthly net income is PHP 7,000. He is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase canned goods, instant noodles, coffee, sugar and bread to sell. He hopes to expand his business further to generate higher profits and sustain his family's daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, instant noodles, coffee, sugar and bread to sell

loans.name: Vita

texts.en:
Vita is a small entrepreneur from Zaporozhye.  She is married.  Vita sells women’s and men’s clothing in the central city market called “Yubileynyi”. She started this business 11 years ago. Presently, she has about 50,000 Grivnas in inventory. Her monthly turnover is 25,000 Grivnas, and her current income is about 6,000 Grivnas each month. 

Vita’s business is self-sustainable. It has passed through different formative stages:  survival, growth and excellence in creating innovations and productivity. Recently, Vita has started a second business location that is also working well.  

Vita is seeking a loan for 12,000 Grivnas to purchase men’s summer shirts.  She is hoping to increase her sales and generate more income with new clothing products.

loans.use: purchase men’s summer shirts

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn, 33 years of age, is married to a factory worker and they are blessed with four children. She has been operating a retail store in their village for almost two years. Her monthly income is 7,000 PHP and she is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase bread, coffee, sugar, canned goods, instant noodles and soft drinks to sell.

She hopes to further expand her business to generate higher profits and to sustain her family's daily needs. She would like to continue availing loans and hopes that Kiva lenders will extend their assistance to her in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bread, coffee, sugar, canned goods, instant noodles and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Sani

texts.en:
This is 39-year-old Sani. She is married and has two children, aged 17 and 14. In 2001, she established her vegetable-farming business. Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy seeds and fertilizers.  

In the future, Sani plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family. She thanks you for your support.   

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Uma

texts.en:
This is 22-year-old Uma.  She is married and has one child, aged 5.  In 2005, she established  her poultry business.  Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy small chicks for her business.  In the future, Uma plans to improve the economic conditions of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, raising poultry for eggs and meat is a very profitable business.  Kiva loans are used to purchase chicks, food, and the medecine needed to keep the chickens healthy.  Once matured, the chickens are sold at small butcher shops or in the many open air markets throughout the valley.  

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: to buy small chickens

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Marites, 30 years of age, is a mother of three. She is married to a laborer in their community. She has operated a typical retail store in their village for almost two years. She's asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase canned goods, oil, instant noodles and bread to sell. Her monthly net income is PHP 7,000. She wanted to expand and improve her business to increase her income and she plans to buy some hogs to raise for additional income. In the future, she hopes to continue to take loans and achieve her dreams for her children through patience and hard work.

loans.use: To purchase canned goods, oil, instant noodles and bread to sell

loans.name: Sabitri

texts.en:
This is 30 year-old Sabitri.  She is married and has two children aged 13 and 7.  In 2005, she established her grocery business.  Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy grocery goods for her business.  In the future, Sabitri plans to improve the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods for her shop

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Aiming to support the education of her five school-aged children, Editha grows rice. She has operated this business for 10 years. Although she is already 45 years old, she is still very strong and dedicated to generating income for the sake of her family.

To make her farming business more profitable, Editha is requesting a loan of PHP 50,000. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and seeds to grow. She will also use some of the loan for the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa, 27 years old, is married, and blessed with one child. She has been operating a retail store for almost seven years and earns a monthly income of PHP 7,000. She requested a loan of PHP 20,000 from ASKI to purchase soap, shampoo, canned goods, cooking ingredients and soft drinks to sell. She hopes that generous lenders will continue to give her financial assistance, to improve and develop her business and she hopes that lenders will continue assisting her in the business so that she can further improve it and support her family with enough basic necessities.

loans.use: to purchase soap, shampoo, canned goods, cooking ingredients and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen, 34 years of age, is married to a farmer. The couple is blessed with three children. She's been engaged in a retail store for almost three years. She's asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase additional grocery items to sell such as coffee, detergent bar, sugar, milk, canned goods and breads. She earns PHP 7,000 monthly in this retailing business. In the future, she would like to continue obtaining loans from Kiva lenders to eventually realize her ultimate business dream of starting another larger business.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items to sell such as coffee, detergent bar, sugar, milk, canned goods and breads

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is 38 years old and married. Geraldine is a farmer working in the Philippines. He earns PHP 25,000 per cropping season.

Geraldine is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase fertilizers and other needed materials. Geraldine has been growing rice for almost 10 years.

In the future, Geraldine hopes that his farming business will be more progressive and support the increasing needs of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other needed materials

loans.name: Benita

texts.en: Benita, 53 years of age, is married to a driver. They are blessed with two children. Benita rents gowns in their village. She has wedding gowns, party gowns, and ordinary gowns in her boutique. She has operated her rental business for almost 27 years. Her monyhly net income is 6,000 PHP. She's asking for a loan for 18,000 PHP to purchase additional gowns to rent. Her loans in the past have been extremely helpful in providing her family's daily needs. She hopes that Kiva lenders will continue to support her.

loans.use: To purchase additional gowns to rent

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is a widow with a teenage son. Natalya lives in Novomoskovsk. She is a market vendor selling boots, galoshes, rubber boots and valenki (felt boots). Natalya owns a kiosk in the central marketplace in her hometown. She has been in this business for 10 years. Her investment in inventory amounts to 50,000 Grivnyas. Her net profit is about 6,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Natalya is seeking a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to purchase summer footwear. She is hoping to attract new customers with additional merchandise. Eventually she hopes to save enough to help her son through college. Her son lives with her at the moment. Natalya is the only breadwinner in her family.

loans.use: to purchase summer footwear

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
This is Salve, who is 40 years old.  She is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Antonio, a security guard, and is mother to their 3 children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating their business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Salve operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Salve earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 600 in sales every day.

To help continue the operations of her business, Salve is requesting a loan for Php 8,000. She will be utilizing this loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Salve hopes to be able to expand and increase her business, and also to teach her children on how to handle the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more inventory

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey is 36 years old.  She resides in the Kampong Chnang province of Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Srey is employed at a garment factory, earning an income of USD 3.33 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband operates a motorbike with a trailer attached to provide transportation services, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 70 on food and USD 40 on other necessary expenses. 

Srey is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business more efficiently. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for her husband's transport business

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:

Sor and her husband are farmers, earning an income of USD 1.5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 10 on other necessary expenses. 

Sor is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice for the family's use. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:

Each month, the family has to spend USD 82 on food and USD 40 on other necessary expenses. 

Kim is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase fertilizer and watermelon seeds to improve their current farming. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and watermelon seeds

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
This is Clarita.  She is 50 years old and is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Danilo, a retired electrician, and is mother to their 3 children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating their business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Clarita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Clarita earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help continue the operations of her business, Clarita is requesting a loan for Php 15,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and rice to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Clarita’s dream is to be able to grow her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more inventory

In the future, Alejandro hopes that his farming business will be more progressive and support the needs of his family.

loans.name: Kou

texts.en:
Kou is 30 years old.  She resides in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products.  Kou is employed at a garment factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3.63 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 66 on food and USD 26 on other necessary expenses. 

Kou is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase palm sugar to resell at the market. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy palm sugar to resell

loans.name: Mireille

texts.en: Mireille  is 25 years old.  She has a one-year-old child who is in school.  Her husband is a mechanic. Mireille sells clothes and is also a tailor.  She has been selling clothes for the past 3 years. This business has helped her meet her family's needs. She is requesting a loan to buy more clothes and expand her business.  With the profits, she plans make some savings and pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Vat

texts.en: Vat resides in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Vat is a farmer, earning an income of 1.5 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. His wife sells groceries, earning an income of 10 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 50 USD on food and 40 USD on the other necessary expenses. Vat is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase more groceries to stock the store. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo is 41 years old and married. He has a retail shop where he sells different goods such as sugar, cooking ingredients, canned goods, soft drinks, milk, shampoo, detergent soap, bar soap, oils, baked breads and other kinds of goods needed in his daily activities. Danilo has had this business for two years and he is grateful because of the improvement he noticed from his business alone. Aside from his general store, he also manages his van for hire. The couple has been blessed with two children and they are generally school-aged. So, Danilo is working hard to sustain the needs of his family and business. Due to the high cost of basic commodities, he would like to have his stocks at his store so that his customers will not always go to market to buy their basic needs. With his goal to buy more stocks of groceries, he is encouraged to take a loan from the microfinance institution.

Danilo is requesting a loan of PHP 50,000 to buy additional groceries such as sugar, oil, biscuits, soft drinks, baked breads and instant noodles; some of the loan will be used to maintain the van. Each month, Danilo earns about PHP 20,000 from his businesses.

In the future,Danilo hopes to expand his store through selling additional groceries needed within the village. He hopes that he will be able to avail his requested loan and fulfill his goals in life.

loans.use: to buy sugar, oil, biscuits, soft drinks, baked breads and instant noodles and to maintain his van.

Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of 1 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 80 USD on food and 40 USD on the other necessary expenses. Say is requesting a loan of 300 USD to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice for the family use. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.name: Nan

This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner. Nan appears in the photograph with her family in the field.

loans.name: Chan

This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy recyclable material to sell

Alice operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Alice earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. She also sells cooked foods and viands at affordable cost.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and cooking ingredients to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Alice's dream is to be able to grow her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

loans.name: Sophin

Sophin is a housewife and her husband is a village chief, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Sophin is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to provide transportation services when he is available from his work. Mao and her husband raise ducks to sell, earning an income of 5 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend 20 USD on food and 40 USD on the other necessary expenses. Mao is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase more ducks to raise for sale. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy ducks to raise for sale

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita is 52 years old and married. She has three adult-aged children. Amelita is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns PHP 7,000 per month. 

Amelita is asking for a loan of PHP 22,000 to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farming needs. Amelita has been growing rice for 10 years.

In the future, Amelita hopes that her farming business will become more progressive and able to support the needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farming needs

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Sokha, 30, resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean sites. Sokha is employed at the garment factory, earning an income of 2 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband grows rice to sell, earning an income of 2 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 15 USD on food and 40 USD on the other necessary expenses. Sokha is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to hire people to help plow and grow rice. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to hire people to help plow the rice fields

loans.name: Rochelle

texts.en:
For some, work is only a means to meet a higher need in life. This is the case of Rochelle, 32. Rochelle graduated from high school, but was not able to continue to college. At present, she is a single mom to one child, whom she loves and cares for dearly. They live in Pasay City with Rochelle’s other family members. Rochelle is also active in her role as a community partner in CCT. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

Rochelle has a store where she cooks meals for customers and sells varieties of daily essentials, from toiletries to instant food. The store is located adjacent to their house for efficient management on her side as she serves her fellow community members. Rochelle has stayed long in the business, and her family helps her in managing the store. She earns around 15, 000 PHP in terms of monthly net income.

To help her sustain her business, which is the primary source of her income, Rochelle applies for a 13,000 PHP loan. Purchasing necessary goods for her store is the main use of this loan. She plans to buy meat, fish, and vegetables to come up with delicious, healthy meals which her customers would surely love. She will also purchase stocks of seasonings, dairy products, and toiletries to meet the needs of her customers. Rochelle says that the loan helps her meet the daily needs of her family, as well as the finances needed for the education of her child.

Rochelle confesses that competition is her toughest challenge at present. There are a lot of stores having the same products that she has, and so she finds it hard to elicit loyalty among her customers. Sometimes the meals she cooked were not all sold, and she was forced to lower the price just to call it a day. But Rochelle never entertains the thought of defeat because her life—and the life of her family—hinges on the success of her business. This is where she will draw money for the medication of her child, the payment of the house bills, and much more. That is why her prayer is for her business to grow profitably and for her family to stay strong and united.



*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for the expansion of her product inventory

loans.name: Taiba

texts.en:
Taiba is married and is the loving mother of three children. Her husband works as a carpenter. She has been running a business selling different kinds of beddings for 12 years.  Taiba sells her products in the market of Isfara city. She sells basically fabrics, bed linens, blankets, unbleached calicos and handkerchiefs. Taiba buys her goods from Khujand city 2-3 times a month.  In the seasonal period from May to August, her daily revenue is about 200-300 TJS. Taiba plans to increase her assortments of fabrics and bed linens to expand her business.  To achieve that goal, she has requested a loan of 9,000 TJS. Let’s help her with this purchase and provide for her needs. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: buy bed linens and fabrics

loans.name: Sokhun

texts.en:
Sokhun is 49 years old.  She resides in Prey Veng province, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. Sokhun is a housewife and a farmer.  Her three children are employed at a factory, each earning an income of USD 2 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 25 on food and USD 25 on other necessary expenses. 

Sokhun is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase cows to help plow her rice fields. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

Her husband makes wooden furniture to sell, earning an income of USD 2.5 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 25 on food and USD 25 on other necessary expenses. 

Yem is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase wood to improve her husband’s business. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy wood to make furniture

loans.name: Sokhun

texts.en:
Sokhun is 38 years old.  She resides in Prey Veng province, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. Sokhun is a housewife.  Her two children are employed at a factory, each earning an income of USD 2 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 30 on food and USD 25 on the other necessary expenses. 

Sokhun is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve the family farming. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is divorced and is raising her 12-year-old son by herself. She is an entrepreneur from Melitopol, where she sells men’s clothing at a local open market. Svetlana has been in this business for 7 years. With the financial assistance of Nadiya Ukraine, she has been able to add variety to her assorted merchandise and to expand considerably. Svetlana’s current income is about 4,500 UAH a month.

Svetlana has a reasonable pricing policy, which attracts customers to her vending facility. This summer season, she is planning to increase her seasonal inventory and is requesting a loan of 15,000 UAH to purchase men’s summer shirts. As a single mother, Svetlana works hard to sustain her family. She is hoping to generate additional income and invest part of the profit into improving her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase men’s summer shirts

loans.name: Tserendorj

texts.en:
Tserendorj, 39, is a skillful craftsman. He lives with his daughter and wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in his brother’s yard. His daughter attends primary school and his wife works at a local kindergarten.

When he first began his business in 2000, Tserendorj made golden and silver jewelry at home. In 2008, he and his brother built his own small workshop with his business earnings. In the past eleven years, he has gained a lot of experience and today he makes various fine works of arts on order.  He was thus able to buy a used car with his business earnings a few months ago.   

Tserendorj is applying for a loan of 2,300,000 MNT to buy silver to make a custom saddle with silver jewelry to sell to his customer. His plan for 2011 is to build his own small house with his business earnings.

loans.use: buy silver needed to make a custom saddle

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 41 years old.  She is a widow and has 6 children who are between 7 and 20 years old.  Rose owns a bar in which she sells different kinds of beer. She has been running this business for 9 years and it has enabled her to improve her standard of living. Rose is requesting a loan to buy beer and fill her bar to make more profits. With the profits, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: buy beer for her bar

loans.name: Saydali

texts.ru: Сайдали проживает в городе Кургантюбе. Ему 35 лет. Он женат. У него трое детей. Его жена, домохозяйка. Сам он занимается торговлей на центральном рынке города. Он арендует торговую точку, где продает необходимые вещи для дома, заколки и бижутерию. Этим видом деятельности занимается 8 лет. Кредит берет для покупки бижутерий, парфюмерии и новых видов заколок.
texts.en: Saydali lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube. He is 35 years old, married, and has three children. His wife is a housewife. He trades in the central market of the city. He rents a shop where he sells household supplies, barrettes, and costume jewelry. He has been doing this work for eight years. He is taking out a loan to buy costume jewelry, perfume, and new kinds of hair accessories.

loans.use: to buy costume jewelry, perfume, and new kinds of hair accessories

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Everyone wants a happy family and Marivic, 49, is no exception. Marivic was a high school graduate. At present, she is a wife to Jose, a construction worker, and a loving mother to four children. Two of her children are already working, while two are studying in high school. Their family resides in Pasay City. Aside from her family and business, Marivic also spends time attending weekly Bible fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

In order to make a living, Marivic sells frozen food from house to house in their community in Pasay. She sees this as an effective strategy since it also gives her a way to build relationships with her customers on a more intimate level. She has been doing this by herself for six years now, and earns a monthly net income of Php 9,000.

To help continue the operation of her business, Marivic is requesting a loan for Php13,000 to help her increase her sales. She will use this to add more to her stocks of processed meat such as hotdogs and sweet ham, as well as pork and chicken meat. She admits that the loan will definitely boost her capital and will serve as a step toward business growth. According to her, part of the profits will be used to finance the schooling of her children, so the loan benefits not only the business but also her family.

One struggle Marivic faces is delayed payments by her customers. Some do not pay in full and leave part of it to debt. Marivic frequently worries about the education of her children, but she fights these struggles and makes sure at the end of the day that she is happy inside out, because a happy family starts with her, the light of their home.  She desires to see her business grow and presently looks for other sources of income. She also prays that her husband and children would have stable jobs and that her two younger children will finish their schooling.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buy frozen food to resell

loans.name: Dalia

texts.en: Dalia is 37 years old.  She has 3 children between 5 and 13 years old who are all in school.  Her husband sells foodstuffs. Dalia owns a bar in which she sells different kinds of beer.  She has been running this business for one year, and it has enabled her to feed her family. Dalia is requesting a loan to buy beer and fill her bar in order to make more profits. With the profits she hopes to make, she plans to buy other types of beer that she doesn’t have.

loans.use: buy beer for her bar

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Zafar

texts.ru: Зафар житель города Кургантюбе. Ему 38 лет. Он женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование у него среднее. Он занимается торговлей на рынке. В основном он занимается продажей необходимых вещей для дома и хоз. товаров. В этой области он уже 5 лет. В продвижении бизнеса ему помогает его сын. Он берет кредит для увеличения ассортимента товара и расширения свой деятельности.
texts.en: Zafar lives in Qurgan-Tube. He is 38 years old, married, and has four children. He has a high school education.  He works trading in the market. Basically he sells things necessary for house and home.  He has been doing this work for five years. His son helps him with his business.  He is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods he sells and to expand his shop.

loans.use: Для увеличения ассортимента товара и расширения своей деятельности

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is 24 years old and married with one four-year old child who attends school. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last five years in Nkubu town, eastern Kenya. Her main products are maize, bananas, beans and milk, which are all sold locally. She earns additional income from her retail shop in the same area.

Millicent has requested a loan of 40,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to cultivate bananas. She says that this loan will enable her to cultivate more bananas, which will increase her production and earn her more income. The proceeds from this project will help her improve her family's livelihood.

Her major challenges have been diseases and lack of enough water for her farm. However, she hopes to expand her banana plantation and acquire a pick-up to assist her in transporting bananas to the market in the near future.

loans.use: To cultivate bananas

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
This is Alma, 34, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Edelberto, a welder, and mother to their two children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to provide continuous income for their everyday expenses.

Alma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Alma earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 41,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, rice and e-load credits to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Alma dreams of being able to grow her business to be a mini grocery store. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en: Bernadette is 48 years old. She has four children who are 16 to 22 years old. She is a widow. She has a small supermarket in which she sells foodstuffs, beers, juices and water. She has owned this supermarket for 17 years and it enables her to pay her children’s school fees and meet her family needs. She is requesting a loan to buy items such as juices, fruits etc for her supermarket. With the profits, together with her savings, she plans to build her own family house.

loans.use: To buy juices, fruits etc. to sell

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
This is Maricel, 36, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a college graduate and a mother of one child in school. At this time, she is working hard to provide continuous income for their everyday expenses and be able to send her child all the way through college.  This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Maricel, as she herself has finished college and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Maricel operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Maricel earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 22,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Maricel hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to have her own house and lot in a prominent subdivision in a nice location. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn is a married woman with two children who are four and five years old.  She is 32 years old and has had a sari-sari store business for four years. Her husband is a fisherman.

Rubelyn sells items like milk in sachets, shampoo and soft drinks to the people in her community. She also helps her husband sell his catch at the market. Rubelyn is requesting a loan to buy more items to sell such as canned goods and soap. Rubelyn hopes to expand her store in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as canned goods and soap

loans.name: Zaid

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 38 years old, married and has two children.

Zaid has had a shop selling kid’s shoes since 1994. He has a lot of experience and a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting a $2200 loan to install aluminum shelves and to increase his purchases. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To install aluminum shelves and purchase more stock

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband and four young children who are still attending school.  She has been running a successful bakery since 2001. She produces tasty Lebanese food. She cooperates with her husband who works in security in a local school to be able to pay the heavy living expenses, especially their children's schooling. This will be her second Kiva loan. She has had a very good repayment history and always repaid on time. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase her purchases of food in order to increase her productivity, her sales and her profits.

loans.use: to increase her purchases of food (ingredients) for her bakery

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 57-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and two children. He has owned a bakery since 2000 with more than 20 years of experience in this occupation. He prepares delicious food and pastries such as pizza, tarts, pies etc.  Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to satisfy his family needs. He has taken advantage of his first Kiva loan and has been a reliable client paying on time. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies such as flour, gas etc. He says that with these purchases, he will be able to increase his productivity and meet his customers’ demands. In the future, he intends to enlarge his business even more.

loans.use: to purchase needed supplies such as flour and gas

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 52 years old and married to Peris who also contributes to the family income. He has four children aged 28, 25, 22, and 18 years. He has been raising pigs on his farm for about one year with an income of 18,600 shillings per month.

He is taking his first loan with KADET after being introduced by a KADET staff member. He wants to use the loan to add to his stock of pig feed, expand the pig project successfully and improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy more pig feed

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor is a 53-year-old married man from the town of Talibon, Bohol. He makes "bahalina" (coconut wine) for a living. Victor sells his product to the people in his community.

Victor has requested a loan to purchase materials for his bahalina business like containers. He hopes for his business to grow and for his family's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase containers for his bahalina (coconut wine) business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm inputs and rabbits.

loans.name: Esperance

texts.en: Esperance is 56 years old with seven children who are ages 14-30 years old. She is a widow. She sells charcoal in the market and she has sold charcoal for three years. This business has improved the standard of living for her family. She is requesting a loan to buy more charcoal and make more profits. With the profits, she plans to build a family house.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Patricidra

texts.en:
Patricidra is a hardworking entrepreneur living in the Philippines. She is 49 years old and married with four school-aged children.

Patricidra sells cosmetics products such as lotion, make-up, powder and lipstick. With these activities, she usually generates PHP 6,000 a month. Most of her customers are her female neighbors. Patricidra has operated this business for almost seven years now. According to her, the business is of great assistance in supporting her family's needs. She is requesting PHP 24,000 to purchase more items to sell like lipstick, foundation and perfumes.

In the future, Patricidra would like to start another business.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell like lipstick, foundation and perfumes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her dairy farm business where she will buy another dairy cow so that she can be able to get more milk from the cow for re sale.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 37 years old and has two children who are ages 8 and 12 years. They are both in school and her husband sells foodstuffs. She is a tailor and she has done this business for five years. She is requesting a loan to buy a tailoring machine in addition to the one she has and make more profits. She plans to save all her profits.

loans.use: To buy a sewing/tailoring machine.

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
This is Epifania, 61, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She has five children. Two of the children are already enrolled in college and three stay at home managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Epifania has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to provide continuous income for their everyday expenses.

Epifania operates a computer rental shop. In the Philippines, very few people own their own computers. Thus, there is a need for them, especially for students who need to do their research and papers. She rents out computers by the hour and offers printing and typing services. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 250 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy additional set of computer parts & accessories needed for the shop. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Epifania dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and were she draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for an additional set of computer parts & accessories

loans.name: Jehly

texts.en:
Jehly, 42 years old, is a married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa Agusan del Sur. She has two children. Her eldest child is 13 years old and her youngest child is 12. She is a rice farmer and has been doing this business for 10 years now.

Aside from rice, she also raises swine to supplement their family income. Her average income for her businesses is PHP 10,000 per month.

Jehly needs a loan to support her livelihood. The loan will help her buy fertilizers and pig feed.

In the future, Jehly hopes to send her children to college. She believes that through God’s provision, she will be able to raise her family well.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pig feed

loans.name: Alibek

texts.en:
Alibek is 53 years old, married and has three children. He is a hardworking man. 

He is a carpenter and in order to make an additional income, he also provides house-building services. Besides this, he is engaged in farming and cultivates potatoes and wheat. He rents land from the neighboring village and cultivates melons and watermelons. 

IMON International’s service is very convenient for Alibek and that’s why he wants to get a loan. Alibek would like to get a loan of 8,000 TJS for purchasing fertilizer and melon seeds. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC, and communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and melon seeds.

loans.name: Lyra Joy

texts.en:
Lyra Joy is 20 years old and married. She has a retail shop where she sells plastic wares, curtains, blankets, towels, kitchen utensils and groceries. Lyra Joy has had this business for two years. Because of patience and sacrifices made by Lyra Joy and her husband, they are able to start another business- a grocery store. 

Lyra Joy is requesting a loan of PHP 12,000 to buy additional plastic ware, curtains, blankets, towels, kitchen utensils and groceries. Each month, Lyra Joy earns about PHP 5,000 on her dry goods and PHP 1500 from her store.

In the future, Lyra Joy hopes to buy more stock of kitchen utensils, towels and other kinds of dry goods and additional groceries such as soft drinks, biscuits, ingredients, oils, sugar and different kinds of baked breads. She will be thankful if her request loan is granted.

loans.use: to buy additional plastic ware, curtains, blankets, towels, kitchen utensils and groceries

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is a married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She is a rice farmer and has been engaged in this business for 10 years now.

Aside from farming, she also has a swine business. She is doing this to supplement their family income. Her average income for her businesses is PHP 1,000.

Rosalina needs support to sustain her livelihood. The loan will help her buy farm supplies like fertilizers and feed. Some will be paid for the school tuition of her children.

In the future, Rosalina hopes to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is 44 years old and married to Emily, who contributes to the family income. He has been running his retail shop for a period of about two years with an income of about KES 5,000 a month. 

He is taking his first loan with KADET Ltd. He wants to use the loan to buy sugar, rice and flour for his retail shop. 

He hopes to expand his business to wholesale and also give his children quality education.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice and flour as additional stock in his retail shop.

loans.name: Dancille

texts.en:
Dancille is 39 years old. She has two children who are ages 15 and 17. They are both in school.

She owns a general store in which she sells food such as green bananas and Irish potatoes (packed in the sacks behind her in the photo). She has done this business for seven years. 

She is requesting a loan to buy more food in order to make more profits. With the profits she hopes to make she plans to build her own family house.

loans.use: To buy more food to resell.

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley grew up in a small village in Sta. Josefa Agusan del Sur. Now, she is 42 years old and married. Her husband is a carpenter. She has three children. Her eldest child is 25 years old while her youngest child is 12. She is a rice farmer and has been doing this business for 10 years now.

Aside from rice, she also raises swine to supplement their family income. Her average income for her businesses is PHP 10,000 per month.

Shirley needs a loan to support her livelihood. The loan will help her buy fertilizers and pig feed.

In the future, Shirley hopes to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Wambui

texts.en:
Wambui is 34 years old and married to Patrick, who contributes to the family income. She has two children who are 13 and 12 years old. She runs a retail shop that she has operated for about five years with a monthly income of 10,000 KES.

This is her second loan with KADET. She repaid the previous one successfully. 

She wants the loan to pay school fees for her children as she has not been able to make enough from her retail business. She hopes to give her children quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Ilyosjon

texts.en: Ilyosjon is a young husband. He is engaged in production of doors and windows. Ilyosjon has been in this business for seven years and he has good experience in this business. This business he learned from a famous master who is from Khujand. Ilyosjon has so many clients who have ordered different fashions of doors and windows from him. Also, he sells his products at the market. Last year, he made a good profit and was able to celebrate his wedding party and repair his house. Today, he would like to purchase wood and dye and expand his business. For this purpose, he requested a loan of 7,000 Tajikistan somoni (TJS). More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy wood and dye.

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
Felicidad is 57 years old and married. She has a retail shop where she sells condiments, sugar, milk, eggs, soft drinks, canned goods, baked breads and biscuits. Felicidad has had this business for one year. She is grateful because her business is improving. 

To continue to improve her general store, Felicidad is requesting a loan of PHP 12,000 to buy more groceries such as condiments, sugar, milk, eggs, soft drinks, canned goods, baked breads and biscuits. Each month, Felicidad earns about PHP 4,000 doing this type of work.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell such as condiments, sugar, milk, eggs, soft drinks, canned goods, baked breads and biscuits

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda is 20 years old and married. She has operated her furniture shop for almost five years. Florenda sells different kinds of furniture such as chairs, cabinets, tables and beds. She is grateful because her business is improving and her customers are increasing because of the quality of the products they make. 

Florenda is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy additional raw materials to make more furniture to sell and to buy feed, supplies and piglets. Each month, Florenda earns about PHP 7,000 in her furniture business.

In the future, Florenda hopes to develop her furniture shop and buy more raw materials so that she can minimize her expenses in going to and from the market. She is praying and hoping that her requested loan will be approved.

loans.use: to buy additional raw  materials

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin, 36 years old, lives in the community of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. He is a rice farmer and a piggery owner. He has been into this business for eight years. His monthly income from his business is 20,000 Philippines pesos (Php).

Through a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc., he can buy farm and agricultural supplies like fertilizers. He could also buy pig feeds and pay the school fees of his children.

Edwin has two sons. His dream is to become a successful rice-farm owner and to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pig feeds.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en: Olive is 25 years old. She has two children who are ages 2 and 6. Her husband sells foodstuffs. Olive sells second-hand clothes, and she has been doing this business for two years. From this business, she has managed to buy a piece a land for which she plans to build a house for her family. She is requesting a loan to buy clothes to sell in order to make more profits. With the profits she hopes to make, she plans to begin construction of her family house.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Buriboy

texts.en:
Buriboy is an active 35 year old father of three children. His wife is a housewife. He is a farmer and has been in this business for 10 years. The income he earns from this business allows him to take care of his family and provide the needs of his children and wife. He started his business with the cultivating of grapes and the processing of sultana raisins both of which he sells. Also Buriboy cultivates onions and wheat. Buriboy is an accurate and honest entrepreneur. Buriboy would like a loan of 7,000 TJS to purchase fertilizer in order to get a good harvest. 
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Alexie

texts.en: Alexie is 36 years old. She has 6 children who are ages 6-13 years old. They are all in school. Her husband is a soldier. Alexie owns a bar in which she sells different kinds of beer. She has done this business for 13 years and the profits from her business have enabled her to meet the needs of her family. Alexie is requesting a loan to buy different kinds of beer. With the profits together with her savings she hopes to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of beer.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita Laspinas is a 57 year old married woman. She lives in the community of Sta. Josefa Agusan del Sur. Her husband is a farmer in their community.  She and her husband till their small rice farm to be able to raise their children.

With a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. Lolita hopes to buy fertilizer, seed and insecticide.

In the future, Lolita hopes to have a bigger farm and more profit for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seed, and insecticide

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en: Jeniffer is 47 years old and married to Samuel who contributes to the family income.  They have 6 children. Jeniffer has a grocery store and also sells milk as a secondary business. She has been in the business for 11 years with a monthly income of about 1,000 Kenya shillings. This is her first loan with the KADET. She wants to use the loan to buy cabbage and kale for her grocery shop. Jeniffer hopes to expand her grocery shop and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to buy cabbage and kale for her grocery shop

loans.name: Elorde

texts.en:
Rice farming is Elorde's way of supporting his family's needs. At the age of 45, he is really working hard just to give the best for his four school-aged children. With his diligence, he is earning PHP 25,000 during harvest season. He saves most of his income for the educational expenses of his children.

Since farming is his main livelihood, Elorde wants to keep on doing this activity and eventually have more hectares of farmland to till. With that, he is requesting a loan of PHP 17,000 to purchase fertilizers, pesticides and other farm inputs that he needs. He believes that with the loan and his perseverance, his dreams will come into reality.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, pesticides and other farm inputs

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
This is Evelyn, 57, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Oscar, a driver, and is the mother to their 7 children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Evelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Evelyn earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 600 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 31,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Evelyn hopes to be able to expand soon to increase her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and were she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Benedetta

texts.en:
Benedetta is 52 years old. She is married to Joseph, who contributes to the family income and they have six children. She has a retail shop where she has been selling different items like bread, sugar and tea leaves for about four years, with an income of about 10,000 Kenyan shillings per month.

She is taking her first loan with the KADET after being introduced to it by a KADET staff member. She wants to use the loan to buy stock of sugar, tea leaves and flour for her retail shop. She hopes to expand her business, to be a wholesaler and to improve her family's living standard.

loans.use: to buy stock of sugar, tea leaves and flour for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man living with his parents and two siblings who are still attending school. He is from Lebanon. He has owned a butcher shop since 2009. Regardless of his young age and years of experience, he is considered as the best butcher in his town serving the most appetizing meat. 

He has obtained his first Kiva loan and has been an excellent client with prompt payments. He helps his father with his income to provide a better standard of living for the family. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase pork needed for his shop. He says that this purchase will help him increase his sales and thereby his income.

loans.use: to purchase pork for his butcher shop.

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo is 50 years old and married. He has seven adult-aged children. Romeo is a farmer working in the Philippines. He earns PHP 10,000 per month. 

Romeo is asking for a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase fertilizers and seeds to grow. Romeo has been growing rice for almost 28 years.

In the future, Romeo hopes that his farming business will become more progressive and support the needs of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to prepare land for farming and to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 46-year-old married man living with his wife and two young children who are still attending school. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a farmer from the past 10 years. In 2006, he bought some land and started farming independently. He cultivates all types of vegetables, and he distributes his products to multiple agricultural markets. 

This will be his second Kiva loan and he notes that he has been able to increase his profits by a large percentage since taking his first loan. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase supplies, such as spices and seeds, in order to make his products grow faster and increase his productivity.

loans.use: to purchase supplies such as spices and seeds

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman who grows crops for a living. Her husband is also a farmer. Together, they till land to grow rice crops and vegetables. Elizabeth said that they have been running the farm for five years. They earn about 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per month from farming. Elizabeth also raises pigs in her backyard. She sells the pigs at the market.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. In the future, she hopes to improve her house and to have a good harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Racheal is 28 years old. Her 2 children are not yet in school, aged 8 months and 3 years old. She separated from her husband and she takes care of the children alone. She sells clothes in the market and she has done this business for 6 years. This business enables her to meet all of her family's needs. 

Racheal is requesting a loan to buy clothes to sell, in order to make more profits. She plans to have savings and also to pay her children’s school fees with the extra profits that she plans to make.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a 44 year old married woman. Her husband works as a farmer. Helen is also a farmer, working in Banga, Agusan del sur. She has been growing rice and corn crops for 4 years. She earns 5,000 PHP per month doing this farming. Helen also owns and manages a sari-sari store. She sells various products such as chips and spices.

This loan will be used to purchase supplies for her farm and also to purchase items for the family. In the future, she hopes to improve their farming business and to have a better life.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for her farm and for the family.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is 26 years old. She is single. She owns a general store in which she sells different kinds of items commonly used at home such as salt, matches, sugar, candles, soap, table dishes, etc. She has done this business for 2 years and this business has enabled her to buy almost all the basic needs she has required. 

Martha is requesting a loan to buy more items and to fill her store in order to make more profits. With the profits, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her general store such as sugar, matches, candles, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary sells sugar and groundnuts. She is 32 years old, married, and has 6 children. None of her children goes to school.

Mary borrowed a loan to stock more sugar and groundnuts to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future with the extra profits.

loans.use: to stock more sugar and groundnuts to sell.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 35 years old and married to John who contributes to the family income. Jane has a knitting shop, which she has been running for a period of about 4 years, with an income of 12,000 Kenya shillings a month.

This is the second loan Jane is receiving from KADET, after successfully repaying the previous one. She wants to use the loan to buy knitting threads and other accessories so that she will be able to knit more items, like cardigans. She hopes to own a big knitting shop and create employment for other people.

loans.use: to buy knitting threads and other accessories.

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en:
Ivy is a married woman with a three-year-old child. Her husband works as a farmer. 

Ivy raises pigs and ducks. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market. She also sells the ducks 'eggs. Ivy also helps her husband grow rice at their farm. Ivy earns about 6000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per month from raising livestock and farming. 

This loan will be used to purchase livestock feed, vitamins, and farm fertilizers. In the future, she hopes to be successful in her livelihood and with her family.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed, vitamins and farm fertilizers

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia is 29 years old. She has three children who are between the ages of one and nine years old; her husband is a driver. Asia sells different kinds of children's clothes in the market. She lays her clothes down for clients to easily see them. Asia has been doing this business for five years, and it has enabled her pay school fees for her children. 

She is requesting a loan to buy more items and expand her business to make more profits. With the profits she hopes to make she plans to put aside some savings.

loans.use: to buy clothes

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina sells fish. She is 38 years old, married, and has three children. None of her children go to school. Regina took out a loan to stock more fish to sell. She hopes to use extra profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to stock more fish to sell.

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
Lerma is 54. She is a married woman and she has 5 children. Her oldest child is now 37 years old.

Lerma is a farmer, working in Banga, Agusan del sur. She primarily grows corn crops to sell. She earns 4,000 PHP per month doing this farming. Lerma also runs a small eatery. She cooks the food herself and sells them to passersby and people in her community.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and raw ingredients for the viands she sells in her eatery. In the future, she hopes to improve her businesses.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and raw ingredients for viands she sells in her eatery.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old married man living with his wife and one school-aged child. He is from Lebanon. He has owned a cattle farm since 2006. He works alone on his farm, producing dairy products such as milk. He sells his products to local markets and many customers upon request. His farm is the only source of income for his family. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 US from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase fodder for his cattle. This will allow his cattle to produce a good quality of milk so that he will be able to increase his sales. In the future, he is willing to buy more cattle in order to increase his business productivity.

loans.use: to purchase fodder for his cattle

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 36 years old. She is married to Patrick, who contributes to the family income. She has 3 children, aged 20, 16, and 5 years old. She has been selling clothes for about 5 years, with an income of 5,000 Kenyan shillings a month.

She is taking her second loan with KADET, after repaying the previous one successfully. She wants the loan to buy more clothes. Her hope is to buy a plot of land and develop rental houses. She would like to give her children a quality education as well as to improve their living standard.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Rose
